learningContentbody.lcInstruction:
Always wrap content in the table in

tags. Forgetting this can result in the content of the table to format in unexpected ways. While the DITA specification allows you to nest tables, it's a Bad IdeaTM. Whenever possible, consider organizing the content in your table to include more rows instead of more columns. When you send the content to an output, pagination issues can make many columns appear in unexpected ways. In many word processing tools, people use tables to visually format content such as indented lists. In DITA, this is not done and can lead to unexpected results. Consider localization text expansion in tables. Where possible, design the content for up to 40% text expansion. The DITA standard allows graphics table cells. In practice, it's best to place just small icons in table cells. Consider the possible outputs when you create tables. Table rendering may very different be on a small screen, such as a mobile device. Consider using non-tables and rendering as table on big screen or big paper. For example: definition lists, which can be rendered as either a table or as a hanging indent (default)
